db:abstract.db:para: Provides APIs to call Java code from C++.
This class was introduced in Qt 5.2.

db:listitem.db:para: Class names needs to contain the fully-qualified class name, for example: "java/lang/String".
All object types are returned as a QAndroidJniObject.

db:section.db:title: Method Signatures
db:section.db:para: For functions that take no arguments, QAndroidJniObject provides convenience functions that will use the correct signature based on the provided template type. For example:

In other cases you will need to supply the signature yourself, and it is important that the signature matches the function you want to call. The signature structure is (A)R, where A is the type of the argument(s) and R is the return type. Array types in the signature must have the [ suffix and the fully-qualified type names must have the L prefix and ; suffix.
The example below demonstrates how to call two different static functions.
The signature for the first function is "(I)Ljava/lang/String;"
and the signature for the second function is "(Ljava/lang/String;Ljava/lang/String;)[Ljava/lang/String;"

db:section.db:title: Handling Java Exception
db:section.db:para: When calling Java functions that might throw an exception, it is important that you check, handle and clear out the exception before continuing.

db:note.db:para: It is unsafe to make a JNI call when there are exceptions pending.

db:section.db:title: Java Native Methods
db:section.db:para: Java native methods makes it possible to call native code from Java, this is done by creating a function declaration in Java and prefixing it with the native keyword. Before a native function can be called from Java, you need to map the Java native function to a native function in your code. Mapping functions can be done by calling the RegisterNatives() function through the JNI environment pointer.
The example below demonstrates how this could be done.
Java implementation:
C++ Implementation:

db:section.db:title: The Lifetime of a Java Object
db:section.db:para: Most objects received from Java will be local references and will only stay valid in the scope you received them. After that, the object becomes eligible for garbage collection. If you want to keep a Java object alive you need to either create a new global reference to the object and release it when you are done, or construct a new QAndroidJniObject and let it manage the lifetime of the Java object.

db:note.db:para: The QAndroidJniObject does only manage its own references, if you construct a QAndroidJniObject from a global or local reference that reference will not be released by the QAndroidJniObject.

db:section.db:title: Other
db:section.db:para: For more information about JNI see: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/technotes/guides/jni/spec/jniTOC.html

db:section.db:title: QAndroidJniObject::QAndroidJniObject()
db:section.db:para: Constructs an invalid QAndroidJniObject.

db:section.db:title: [explicit] QAndroidJniObject::QAndroidJniObject(const char *className)
db:section.db:para: Constructs a new QAndroidJniObject by calling the default constructor of className.

db:section.db:title: [explicit] QAndroidJniObject::QAndroidJniObject(int object)
db:section.db:para: Constructs a new QAndroidJniObject around the Java object object.

Note: The QAndroidJniObject will hold a reference to the Java object object and release it when destroyed. Any references to the Java object object outside QAndroidJniObject needs to be managed by the caller.

db:section.db:title: [explicit] QAndroidJniObject::QAndroidJniObject(const char *className, const char *signature, ...)
db:section.db:para: Constructs a new QAndroidJniObject by calling the constructor of className with signature and arguments.

db:section.db:title: [explicit] QAndroidJniObject::QAndroidJniObject(int clazz, const char *signature, ...)
db:section.db:para: Constructs a new QAndroidJniObject from clazz by calling the constructor with signature and arguments.

db:section.db:title: [noexcept] QAndroidJniObject::~QAndroidJniObject()
db:section.db:para: Destroys the QAndroidJniObject and releases any references held by the QAndroidJniObject.

db:section.db:title: QAndroidJniObject QAndroidJniObject::callObjectMethod(const char *methodName, const char *signature, ...) const
db:section.db:para: Calls the Java object's method methodName with the signature signature and arguments

db:section.db:title: [static] QAndroidJniObject QAndroidJniObject::callStaticObjectMethod(const char *className, const char *methodName, const char *signature, ...)
db:section.db:para: Calls the static method with methodName and signature on the class className.

db:section.db:title: [static] QAndroidJniObject QAndroidJniObject::callStaticObjectMethod(int clazz, const char *methodName, const char *signature, ...)
db:section.db:para: Calls the static method with methodName and signature on class clazz.

db:section.db:title: [static] QAndroidJniObject QAndroidJniObject::fromString(const QString &string)
db:section.db:para: Creates a Java string from the QString string and returns a QAndroidJniObject holding that string.

db:section.db:title: QAndroidJniObject QAndroidJniObject::getObjectField(const char *fieldName, const char *signature) const
db:section.db:para: Retrieves the object from the field with signature and fieldName.

db:note.db:para: Since Qt 5.3 this function can be used without a template type.

db:section.db:title: [static] QAndroidJniObject QAndroidJniObject::getStaticObjectField(const char *className, const char *fieldName, const char *signature)
db:section.db:para: Retrieves the object from the field with signature and fieldName on class className.

db:note.db:para: Since Qt 5.3 this function can be used without a template type.

db:section.db:title: [static] QAndroidJniObject QAndroidJniObject::getStaticObjectField(int clazz, const char *fieldName, const char *signature)
db:section.db:para: Retrieves the object from the field with signature and fieldName on clazz.

db:note.db:para: Since Qt 5.3 this function can be used without a template type.

db:section.db:title: [static] bool QAndroidJniObject::isClassAvailable(const char *className)
db:section.db:para: Returns true if the Java class className is available.

db:section.db:title: bool QAndroidJniObject::isValid() const
db:section.db:para: Returns true if this instance holds a valid Java object.
db:section.db:programlisting: ... QAndroidJniObject qjniObject; ==> isValid() == false QAndroidJniObject qjniObject(0) ==> isValid() == false QAndroidJniObject qjniObject("could/not/find/Class") ==> isValid() == false ...

db:section.db:title: QString QAndroidJniObject::toString() const
db:section.db:para: Returns a QString with a string representation of the java object. Calling this function on a Java String object is a convenient way of getting the actual string data.
db:section.db:programlisting: QAndroidJniObject string = ...; // "Hello Java" QString qstring = string.toString(); // "Hello Java"

db:section.db:title: bool operator!=(const QAndroidJniObject &o1, const QAndroidJniObject &o2)
db:section.db:para: Returns true if o1 holds a reference to a different object then o2.

db:section.db:title: bool operator==(const QAndroidJniObject &o1, const QAndroidJniObject &o2)
db:section.db:para: Returns true if both objects, o1 and o2, are referencing the same Java object, or if both are NULL. In any other cases false will be returned.
